The reason theologians study heresy is to avoid falling into it.  Might not the study of scientific error have a similar effect on scientists?

Many of the discoveries were made for reasons that seem whacky. Kepler's harmony of the spheres was the 3rd law of planetary motion. Newton's theory of gravity was influenced by his alchemical and religious studies. The attitude that history is just entertaining and interesting is the problem. It is the study of humanity and our integration into nature. Astrology, perhaps a silly science, was a very interesting natural philosophy that influenced everything from religion to the concept of force. Scientists all too often believe that their mission is the most important mission ever... an uncritical belief that science and technology will solve our most pressing problems. But, could it be that many of our most pressing problems were caused by science and technology? That is a big reason to study the history of science.... to examine the bigger picture... to explore ethical implications... to think about morality... to think about why we study science at all. Today's atomic theory will probably look silly in 200 years... probably look absurd in 1000 years.
The plum pudding model was not a misstep... it was a step. The geocentric model was not a misstep. In the hands of Ptolemy and subsequent Islamic astronomers, it was highly accurate. If people didn't stop to wonder how the physics worked it might still be with us. Those people who wondered about the physics were entertained and interested in history. Science is history.
well for one thing, history of science might make scientists a little more humble and modest in their claims to know the truth about everything.

Studying the history of science may be interesting and entertaining, but I don't see the study of a geo-centric solar system helping astronomers, luminiferous aether helping physicists, or the Plum pudding model of an atom helping chemists. I prefer spending my effort looking forward at how we can use the best insights available into the physical world to make it a better place, rather than looking backward at all the mis-steps we took on the journey.

Thanks for linking to Skeptical Science's John Mason's deconstruction of David Rose's disingenuous escapade. Two gems from that piece:

"…arguing with some climate change contrarians is similar to attempting debate with a well-trained parrot. Imagine: the parrot has memorised some twenty statements that it can squawk out at random. Thus it will follow up on 'no warming since 1997' with 'in the 1970s they said there'd be an ice-age' and so on."

And this on the big picture:

"It is also necessary to consider again that such [surface temperature] projections deal only with near-surface air temperatures and that climate change does not just involve the atmosphere, but the land itself, the rivers, lakes and oceans and the ice of the cryosphere. All are capable of accumulating, transporting and exchanging heat energy."

Finally, two points about the immediate focus of Andy's article, the great Arctic meltdown. One, the late-summmer ice is disappearing, and will be gone soon, though no one knows exactly when. 75% of the pre-1979 ice has already disappeared, and at that rate the rest should be gone around 2025 at the latest.

But more important than whether there are a few cubic kilometers of ice left in 2020 or 2030 is the overall rapid warming of the Arctic region that is raising havoc with the jet stream, melting permafrost and releasing methane, disrupting Arctic Ocean ecosystems and influencing the oceanic conveyor belts. We're in trouble.

Anyone who wants to look can know exactly what the Fed does. It is the most transparent financial organization in the world. It publishes its balance sheet every week, on Thursday. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York publishes its purchases of Treasury securities daily and weekly inventory lists of the securities it owns. For example on 9/17 purchases totaled $1.474 billion and included $252 million of cusip number 912810QQ4, 4.375% coupon, 30 year bonds, maturing 5/15/2041. The details of the bids are not released immediately, but when the open market desk bought $56 million of the same bonds on 8/29 they paid a weighted average price of 112.136 and a least favorable accepted price of 112.14062500. On 9/11 the Fed held $24.378 billion of that bond.

The weekly balance sheet can be found at:
http://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/h41/Current/
and the weekly inventory of holdings can be accessed from:
http://www.newyorkfed.org/markets/soma/sysopen_accholdings.html

Almost all the money the Fed is spending on these purchases is not going anywhere -- it is staying at the Fed. Since the $85 billion a month purchases were announced a year ago, Fed security holdings, including unamortized premiums net of discounts, increased by $861.6 billion, but deposits of banks at the Fed increased by $772.7 billion, so net about $88.9 billion was injected into the economy. The banks are earning 0.25% on those deposits instead of the 3% or 4% someone was earning on the bonds.
